content.p: Consider the integral \displaystyle\iint_D {{fxy}}\ \ dx \ dy where D is the region bound by lines y={{y1}}, y={{y2}}, y={{y3}}.
Use the substitutions x={{xuv}}, y={{yuv}} to rewrite this integral in terms of u, v.

outtro.p: Using the substitutions x={{xuv}}, y={{yuv}}, we have that the line y={{y1}} becomes the line v=0, y={{y2}} becomes the line u={{c}}, and y={{y3}} becomes the line v={{m}}u.

Since \frac{\partial(x,y)}{\partial(u,v)}=\text{det}\,\begin{bmatrix}{{xu}} & {{xv}} \\ {{yu}} & {{yv}} \end{bmatrix}={{Jacob}} We have \displaystyle \iint_D {{fxy}}\ \ dx \ dy = \int_0^{ {{c}} } \int_0^{ {{m}}u } \left|{{Jacob}}\right|\cdot \left({{fuv}}\right)\ dv\ du={{integ}}.
